articles.title: Getting Started
articles.description: Your first Shiny app, how to get started.
articles.contents:
Contents
Templates
Operating the app
Viewer options
Run and Stop

File Name

Getting an app started begins with just a .R file. There are some choices to make in the beginning: a single file app or a multi-page one. It will depend on how you like to organize your code, how much code there will be, and the number of collaborators for the app. For this first part of the session, we will learn with a single file app.
Templates
You can write from scratch or you can open a template to get a head start.
Click the drop down on the New File icon  and select Shiny Web App
The Application Name will be the name of the directory storing your app file.
Select Single File
Save it inside the intro-shiny project directory or another place.

Operating the app
Viewer options
Before you hit Run App  the drop down offers several options for viewing:
Run in Window (RStudio’s pop-up browser)
Run in Viewer Pane
Run External (your default browser)
Run and Stop
After clicking Run App, your app will be running locally and your R session will be listening to the localhost. Your console will not respond.
Click on the stop sign icon  to stop your app and resume your R session. If running externally, closing your default browser window does not stop the app.
File Name
The file name when using a single file app must be called app.R in order to deploy properly.
For teaching and learning purposes, the files provided for this module will use a different naming system to show app development at different stages.

articles.title: Intro to Shiny
articles.contents:
Date: TBDInstructor: Christy LamAssistants: Hana Ševčíková, Craig Helmann, Suzanne Childress, Polina Butrina




Shiny is a package that allows you to easily build interactive web applications. Web development skills aren’t required–all you need is R!
In this two part module, we’ll walk through how to get started, peek inside the anatomy of a Shiny app, and incorporate packages (from previous modules and some new ones!) to build a polished product.

articles.title: Pre-work
articles.contents:
Contents
Install
Test
Optional
Rainbow Parenthesis
Multiple Source columns
shinyapps.io


Install
R and the RStudio IDE are required. See the first module on R Basics for guidance.
Install the following packages by running the following code snippet in the console of your RStudio IDE. Ignore any warnings regarding Rtools and if you are asked to install from sources which needs compilation, click ‘No’.

Some may have already been installed from previous modules. You can adapt the code snippet accordingly.


install.packages(c("shiny", "shinythemes", "DT", "here", "rsconnect", 
                   "tidyverse", "scales", "plotly", "data.table", "sf", "leaflet"))



Test
Test to make sure Shiny works by copying and pasting the code snippet into the console of the RStudio IDE.


library(shiny)
if (interactive()) {
  shinyApp(
    ui <- fluidPage(
      selectInput("variable", "Variable:",
                  c("Cylinders" = "cyl",
                    "Transmission" = "am",
                    "Gears" = "gear")),
      tableOutput("data")
    ),
    server <- function(input, output) {
      output$data <- renderTable({
        mtcars[, c("mpg", input$variable), drop = FALSE]
      }, rownames = TRUE)
    }
  )
}



Optional
Rainbow Parenthesis

Turn on rainbow parenthesis. There’ll be a lot of nested parenthesis and brackets so this is a helpful visual tool to keep track of their counterparts.
Tools > Global Options > Code > Display 


This feature is available in RStudio version 1.4 and beyond.
Multiple Source columns

Activate multiple Source columns. When working with a multi-page app, having at least 2 files opened side-by-side might be more ergonomic. After adding additional columns, you can open scripts and drag and drop them in either column.
Click on the pane icon . Pane Layout... > Add Column


This feature is available in RStudio version 1.4 and beyond.
shinyapps.io

Create a free shinyapps.io account. If you want to deploy a project (non-PSRC related and not something with confidential or sensitive data), shinyapps.io is an option.
Note that deleting an account requires you to contact support@rstudio.com.


shinyapps.io, an app hosting service by RStudio, offers a free account option, but with limitations.
